Posted: August 18, 2013
												I bought this becuase I had no idea what all these lego games were like.  I have only played it about 2 hours and I really have to force myself to play it so I am guessing these kinds of games are not for me.Basically it is a scripted story with a collecting mechanic.  The basic game play is:Watch a cinematic, then act out some event from the story, such as sneaking out of the shire while the dark riders are looking for you.   In between these events are semi-open areas (which I think you can eventually get fast travel to and take the story your own pace).  This is where the collecting comes in.  There are NPCs with missions who want certain objects.  So you run around trying to find and collect these objects.I find this kind of game play very dull and so, my interest in the game is fairly weak.  You could watch some lets play of the beginning of the game (it would take several hours to get enough game-play to make a good judgement) on if you would like it.One problem I suppose is that I already know the LOTR story so well that the whole story aspect doesn't offer me any incentive to play the game.  That is probably the big reason this game does not appeal to me.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												This might be the best Lego game yet.  It's definitely Lord of the Rings, with the strong story, setting and atmosphere - and yet its all Lego, with the silliness and sandbox gameplay you come to expect.The map is brilliant - much better than hanging around in the Cantina or the Batcave, you can roam around all of Middle Earth while you're not doing missions.  The addition of quests is very nice, as is the additional puzzles outside of the combat playgrounds.Instead of episodic gameplay, this game manages to keep the transitions from being jarring between gameplay modes, which helps keep the illusion in place that its one seamless epic.Great game!

Posted: February 3, 2014
												Con: Sometimes buggier than other Lego gamesPros:They put more effort into this game than others.  More diverse, interesting levelsBest character selection of any game yetThe regular group of "skills" needed to beat a level fits a "fellowship" wellThe voice clips from the movies are great... and often set up great comedyThe hub world is awesome: you can walk from Bilbo's front door all the way to Mount DoomMost refined Lego game yet, in terms of co-op, ease of access, and so onOverall this is a great buy, even if you don't play it today, get it on sale... someday you will be glad you did.

Posted: November 16, 2013
												LEGO: The Lord of the Ringsby DaniAngione----------------------------Art - 10 / 10Sound - 9 / 10Gameplay - 8 / 10Emotional - 9 / 10Community - 5 / 10----------------------------Overall - 8.2----------------------------Okay, so this is an easy one: It's LEGO. And it's The Lord of the Rings. TOGETHER. There's no possible way this could go wrong, right?Indeed!Before anything I'd like to admit this is not my first playthrough of this game. I've beaten it on the alternative (AKA Torrent download) version but - hey - I did bought it after all, it actually deserved it.It's basically a LEGO "action-rpg" (more action, less rpg) experience around Middle Earth, following the story of the Lord of the Rings movie trilogy but also containing some neat candy for those lore-freaks (oops) like the stone trolls and the troll hoard - for example. The gameplay is that expected from a LEGO game: puzzles, basic combat, more puzzles, a lot of stuff to collect. It's not the gameplay that makes this game shine, tho. It's the around an hour and a half (plus mid-mission scenes) of rendered cutscenes full of the purest strain of Lord of The Rings Awesomeness.Seriously, they're worthy every nickel you could spend on this game.Not only they were smart enough to use the original movie dialogue for all the scenes brilliantly but they also managed to recapture the magic of Peter Jackson's trilogy and twist it into their own LEGO style. They're amazing and I can't describe them well enough - just buy it and see it yourself!Full of nice and fun moments, good jokes - some even going into the world of inside jokes and internet memes (They're taking the Hobbits to Isengard!) - and, well, LEGO and LOTR together - I dare say that this is the best single-player Lord of the Rings yet.And I mean it!

Posted: June 20, 2015
												This game is a lot like other Lego games. It's a mad romp through your favorite world, and it's a lot of fun. I really enjoyed it. But, it's not quite as good as Lego Starwars III, or Lego The Hobbit. The normal Lego game system is pretty easy to grasp. You can play through the story, where you play as the characters who were there in the book or movie, and then, at the end, unlock the ability to play as them in other missions, and use their special abilities to unlock secrets. Lego: The Lord Of The Rings does this very well, with the Mithril Bricks, Minikits, True Adventurer, etc. The missions are loads of fun, with puzzles that are a tad glitchy, to those that are well designed, but hard!So, the reason that this game is not as good as some of the others from Lego, is that it's just not quite as... I'm not sure. But my other two Lego games, which I mentioned above, have a pizzaz that Lego:TLOTR just doesn't have. It's still a great game (although, if you play without a controller, finding your way around middle earth is an absolute nightmare, because the camera angle is never where you want it), and I heartily recommend it. But only if you've played through the other games first, and want some more.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												This game isn't challenging and you will have to replay levels. the combat isn't great and most puzzles are solved by breaking and building. however the game is very charming. Actual lines from the movies are used, sometimes out of context to tell the story of all 3 books rather well while keeping it simple and humourous. While the humour might not tickle everyone all the time some parts made even an old sourpuss like me crack a smile and sometimes a chuckle. A great game for people who want to get into lord of the rings or just for fans who want to shut their brains off and relax for a few hours to run around an impressive overwolrd or play some of the very well designed story based levels.

Posted: January 29, 2015
 Rating:  9.5/10 Short Version:  Must for Lord of the Rings fans LEGO humor Epic music Open-world of Middle Earth-what’s more to add? Use a controller (or you’re gonna have a bad time) No, you’re not too old to enjoy it A few weird camera angles that impede progress A couple buggy achievements (read a guide to get the bugged ones) Mini Novel Version: I bought this out of impulse on sale (75% off) and the moment I started playing, I did not  in the slightest  regret my decision. Actually, I was disappointed I didn’t grab The Hobbit-LEGO while it was on sale too. (I bought it the second the title went on sale again, since LEGO titles seem to go on sale pretty often.) What first sold me was watching the re-created movie cut scenes with the twist of LEGO humor. There’s about an hour and a half worth of cut scenes, which are definitely not a waste of time. The “voice acting” is audio clips from the movies so it’s obviously spot on. And the music consists of the same majestic scores you hear in the movies, making simple tasks like lighting a fire 1000x more epic.If you’re going for 100% completion on the game, it’s going to take time: probably 30-40 hours. I’ve logged 37 hours and I’m at 82% completion, but I do mess around. You get to unlock pretty much every conceivable character mentioned in the movies (and some from the books, like Tom Bombadil) which allows you do things like  ride a sheep around the Shire as Sauron.  Now tell me that didn’t make a “Thank you for your purchase!” email arrive in your inbox. The entire world of Middle Earth is your sandbox.As a side note, I definitely suggest using a controller. The controls are pretty wonky and unnatural if you want to stay true to keyboard/mouse.Really the only drawbacks would be (1) that you don’t have much control over the camera angles, which makes some areas hard to navigate, but those instances are minimal. (2) The fact that since it is a game made for a controller, it’s a “one button does everything” control system so you’ll definitely end up dropping an object instead of using it a few times. And finally (3) if you’re an achievement hunter, there’s a couple buggy achievements, so I suggest you seek out a guide to overcome them.But all and all, it’s a great game if you want to kick back, enjoy Middle Earth, and hit things with a frying pan ‘till money bursts out. Oh, did I mention that there’s a “Mithril Disco Phial” that plays a remix song of famous LOTR quotes that your characters rock out to? Yeah, just buy it.

The open world is fun to explore, the main quest line is filled with the typical LEGO humor while staying true to the movies, and the crafting adds a nice twist compared to previous LEGO games i've played.  All in all, i highly recommend the game; it's a blast at any age.As far as negatives, about the only complaints i have can be summed up in 2 points.  One, i wish the "open world" was more open; there are many areas that look like you should be able to get to that you either hit an invisble wall or "bounced" back to a safe spot - something that always irks me in games.  Second, there are quite a few random bugs to be found.  Getting your character stuck on a shrub or rock, objects that don't break when they are supposed to, and several reported "100% denying" issues where the save doesn't record you completing objectives that you can't complete a second time.  Personally i haven't ran into any of the last, but there are quite a few reports of people who have, so i recomend being cautious when going for a 100% completion.  About the only other negative i can think of is the fact that you can only use 4 save slots, something i find ridiculous for any PC game.  I realize it's a port, but still - there's just no reason to limit the number of saves on essentially any platform nowadays.  Other than that, i've highly enjoyed this faithful-to-the-source game, and recomend it to anyone looking for a casual, fun time!

Posted: March 14, 2015
												A fantastic retelling of the film trilogy with plenty of humour and puzzles to solve. There's a good 40+ hours of gameplay and it's the first game that I've actually wanted to complete 100% for about 15 years. The audio and dialog come straight from the film so everything feels spot on. The sandbox portion of the game allows you to explore a reasonably large recreation of middle earth with lots of nooks and crannies to discover along the way. There are also events scattered across the world such as the Battle of Helm's Deep, Climbing the secret stairs, and Wethertop that you'll need to revisit once you've unlocked more characters.If there was a criticism I would make of this game it would be that there are few annoying bugs that get in the way of a perfect experience. During the game certain treasures are hidden in difficult to find spots and the route to collect them requires you to change frequently between characters. In single player you have an AI controlled sidekick, so switching to the same character as your sidekick will give you control of the AI character. Your previously controlled character will then become AI controlled. Normally when holding down the change character button you'll get a menu of available characters, unless it seems you are on the edge of a ledge or hanging from a rope. In this case the control will immediately switch to the other character and your character who is hanging on the ledge will under control of AI decide to jump down to join you on the ground. This can be very annoying when trying to complete some of the game's extensive climbing puzzles ( i.e. Isengard ).There are also a number of HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE jumping puzzles that use fixed cameras. I must have attempted some of these 40 or 50 times before I managed to complete them. There doesn't seem to be any jumping assist code for ropes  unlike legolas' swinging poles, so these may prove difficult for some people to pull off.Overall I would say that Lego Lord of the Rings is a very polished and lovingly crafted experience and the few flaws it has can be ignored when you consider how much fun you are having with the rest of the game.

Posted: November 16, 2013
												LEGO: The Lord of the Ringsby DaniAngione----------------------------Art - 10 / 10Sound - 9 / 10Gameplay - 8 / 10Emotional - 9 / 10Community - 5 / 10----------------------------Overall - 8.2----------------------------Okay, so this is an easy one: It's LEGO. And it's The Lord of the Rings. TOGETHER. There's no possible way this could go wrong, right?Indeed!Before anything I'd like to admit this is not my first playthrough of this game. I've beaten it on the alternative (AKA Torrent download) version but - hey - I did bought it after all, it actually deserved it.It's basically a LEGO "action-rpg" (more action, less rpg) experience around Middle Earth, following the story of the Lord of the Rings movie trilogy but also containing some neat candy for those lore-freaks (oops) like the stone trolls and the troll hoard - for example. The gameplay is that expected from a LEGO game: puzzles, basic combat, more puzzles, a lot of stuff to collect. It's not the gameplay that makes this game shine, tho. It's the around an hour and a half (plus mid-mission scenes) of rendered cutscenes full of the purest strain of Lord of The Rings Awesomeness.Seriously, they're worthy every nickel you could spend on this game.Not only they were smart enough to use the original movie dialogue for all the scenes brilliantly but they also managed to recapture the magic of Peter Jackson's trilogy and twist it into their own LEGO style. They're amazing and I can't describe them well enough - just buy it and see it yourself!Full of nice and fun moments, good jokes - some even going into the world of inside jokes and internet memes (They're taking the Hobbits to Isengard!) - and, well, LEGO and LOTR together - I dare say that this is the best single-player Lord of the Rings yet.And I mean it!

												The licence has been handled well, with several key scenes from the movies recreated exactly - shot-for-shot. This only really becomes a problem if you're striving for 100% completion but it does hinder pgoress or require you to restart levels a couple of times on a normal playthrough as well.  The formula for Lego games has remained virtually unchanged for a while now; the addition of voiced characters here is a welcome one and inevitable given the subject matter.  As with all of the Lego games, it is essentially a console port so it is best played with a controller.

												Should Legos talk? Yeah, probably. This is a fun, if simple game with a ton to do. The story mode is fun to play through, and then there's a ton of collectables to seek out as you unlock different characters. Unless you're actually playing through for the story, this is basically a good game to toddle about in as you listen to a podcast or something. It's easy (I mean, I'm pretty sure it's mainly targeted as a kid's game), but it's a fun thing to mess around with.It's also worth nothing that this has come a long way since LEGO Star Wars, the last one of these games that I played. I went back to Star Wars recently and they seem primitive by comparison.It's not terribly original, but if you like LEGO games and you like Lord of the Rings, you'll like this. It's also probably a good LEGO game to jump in on, since it does a pretty good job of guiding you through things, with the exception of a few obtuse "puzzle" designs.

 Rating:  9.5/10 Short Version:  Must for Lord of the Rings fans LEGO humor Epic music Open-world of Middle Earth-what’s more to add? Use a controller (or you’re gonna have a bad time) No, you’re not too old to enjoy it A few weird camera angles that impede progress A couple buggy achievements (read a guide to get the bugged ones) Mini Novel Version: I bought this out of impulse on sale (75% off) and the moment I started playing, I did not  in the slightest  regret my decision. Actually, I was disappointed I didn’t grab The Hobbit-LEGO while it was on sale too. (I bought it the second the title went on sale again, since LEGO titles seem to go on sale pretty often.) What first sold me was watching the re-created movie cut scenes with the twist of LEGO humor. There’s about an hour and a half worth of cut scenes, which are definitely not a waste of time. The “voice acting” is audio clips from the movies so it’s obviously spot on. And the music consists of the same majestic scores you hear in the movies, making simple tasks like lighting a fire 1000x more epic.If you’re going for 100% completion on the game, it’s going to take time: probably 30-40 hours. I’ve logged 37 hours and I’m at 82% completion, but I do mess around. You get to unlock pretty much every conceivable character mentioned in the movies (and some from the books, like Tom Bombadil) which allows you do things like  ride a sheep around the Shire as Sauron.  Now tell me that didn’t make a “Thank you for your purchase!” email arrive in your inbox. The entire world of Middle Earth is your sandbox.As a side note, I definitely suggest using a controller. The controls are pretty wonky and unnatural if you want to stay true to keyboard/mouse.Really the only drawbacks would be (1) that you don’t have much control over the camera angles, which makes some areas hard to navigate, but those instances are minimal. (2) The fact that since it is a game made for a controller, it’s a “one button does everything” control system so you’ll definitely end up dropping an object instead of using it a few times. And finally (3) if you’re an achievement hunter, there’s a couple buggy achievements, so I suggest you seek out a guide to overcome them.But all and all, it’s a great game if you want to kick back, enjoy Middle Earth, and hit things with a frying pan ‘till money bursts out. Oh, did I mention that there’s a “Mithril Disco Phial” that plays a remix song of famous LOTR quotes that your characters rock out to? Yeah, just buy it.

												This game helps me appreciate the movies a bit more through its abridgement and voice clips.  It's also a fun game.  Things to note though:.1. Don't bother exploriing the overworld until you beat the game.  It railroads you through to the end, giving you little chance to explore, buy characters, get mithril blocks, and do Free Play properly.2. This game does have the occasional glitch, including two notable ones that forced me to restart the level.  There are statues that let you save in the middle of levels.  Don't overlook them.3. 												I didn't have a ton of prior experience with Lego games but I am a big fan of LOTR. It is a blast to play through and I really enjoyed the light hearted take on the series. Posted: February 8, 2014
												This is another success in the Lego series of game. The only one i had previously played before this one was the Star Wars saga game which i really enjoyed so i was glad to see they had expanded on a winning formula and managed to keep fun as the main feature of this game. This game still has the wacky humour of previous games although has included the voces for characters instead of having mute characters. It still has all the stuff standard to all the Lego games like collecting studs in levels to use as currency, loads of characters with different abilities and collecting minikits as well as some new stuff. You have a nice open world middle earth to explore so you travel from level to level through middle earth. The open world has characters that give you quests to collect items found in the levels or craft them from mithril bricks which you can collect  in the open world or from completing levels. The items you craft also can be useful as well as being weird and funny The game is pretty easy to beat in story mode but the real fun is repeating those levels in free mode where you can use any character and item you've unlocked to play through the level which lets you collect items or explore areas you wouldn't be able to reach in story mode. It's a lot more difficult to try and collect everything in this game as there's just so much.The only complaint i have with this game is i found it to be quite buggy. There was a couple of occassions where i couldn't complete a level because of bugs (for example in one level all Frodo's items dissappeared from his inventory and i couldn't go any further because there was one i had to use). However while annoying it didn't happen often enough to be a major nuisance.So overall i'd recommend this game to everyone especially if you enjoy the Lord Of The Rings films or books. It may be aimed towards a younger audience but even as an adult i really enjoyed it. It's a great game to just pick up and play when you want to relax and just play a fun game. It's a 9/10 for me.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												A fantastic retelling of the film trilogy with plenty of humour and puzzles to solve. There's a good 40+ hours of gameplay and it's the first game that I've actually wanted to complete 100% for about 15 years. The audio and dialog come straight from the film so everything feels spot on. The sandbox portion of the game allows you to explore a reasonably large recreation of middle earth with lots of nooks and crannies to discover along the way. There are also events scattered across the world such as the Battle of Helm's Deep, Climbing the secret stairs, and Wethertop that you'll need to revisit once you've unlocked more characters.If there was a criticism I would make of this game it would be that there are few annoying bugs that get in the way of a perfect experience. During the game certain treasures are hidden in difficult to find spots and the route to collect them requires you to change frequently between characters. In single player you have an AI controlled sidekick, so switching to the same character as your sidekick will give you control of the AI character. Your previously controlled character will then become AI controlled. Normally when holding down the change character button you'll get a menu of available characters, unless it seems you are on the edge of a ledge or hanging from a rope. In this case the control will immediately switch to the other character and your character who is hanging on the ledge will under control of AI decide to jump down to join you on the ground. This can be very annoying when trying to complete some of the game's extensive climbing puzzles ( i.e. Isengard ).There are also a number of HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE jumping puzzles that use fixed cameras. I must have attempted some of these 40 or 50 times before I managed to complete them. There doesn't seem to be any jumping assist code for ropes  unlike legolas' swinging poles, so these may prove difficult for some people to pull off.Overall I would say that Lego Lord of the Rings is a very polished and lovingly crafted experience and the few flaws it has can be ignored when you consider how much fun you are having with the rest of the game.

												I'm writing this as someone who has 100% of the achievements.If you're a fan of the LEGO games, or of Lord of the Rings, you'll love this game. Posted: March 7, 2015
--- THE LORD OF THE BUGS ---Traveller's Tales, once again, surprised me with its incredible care in recreating the world and events of a saga into a Lego game. This time, the game is open world, which really surprised me, given that all the others were only levels, and all of the voices are those of the movies. From the beginning to the end, I enjoyed seeing how the adaptation went.HOWEVER, everything came crashing down when I went for the 100%. There are a ridiculous amount of bugs when you replay the levels in free play. Itens that don't appear, invisible walls, disappearing itens and a lot more - and not the kind of that only appear once in a while; it happens all the time. And during the free play you begin to realise the horrible gameplay and controls which are the same since the first LEGO Star Wars - it's outdated and just doesn't work anymore. Several characters that you buy are only copies of ones you already have, and more than half the itens you collect are useless.I looked on foruns, and there are people who COULDN'T ACHIEVE 100% BECAUSE OF BUGS. It was almost my case as well. They informed Traveller's Tales of this and, instead of fixing it, sended cheat codes to unlock the itens - basically, they're not gonna fix then.Only play this if you don't intend to achieve 100%. Otherwise, skip it and go play some other LEGO game less buggy.Not even my love for Tolkien's saga and the LEGO franchise made me tolerate this.

Posted: October 13, 2016
												Lego: The Lord of the Rings is a game that exceeded my expectations. That said, I was not expecting much when I bought it when it was on sale. However, I was thoroughly entertained from start to finish by the amusing cutscenes, and enjoyed the easy-going nature of the game. As a fan of the books and movies, I have to say that this is a game worthy of them. The art direction is beautiful. I think that the world of Lego and Middle-earth was well melded. Certain drawbacks would be the inability to roam around freely to other parts when the storyline has not been completed. I found myself having to multi-task (as a single player) to get the treasure boxes. But this doesn't draw away the fact that this is a really fun game. I'm going to go back to the game and find friends to play co-op with, and roam about with, too.

Posted: August 18, 2013
												I bought this becuase I had no idea what all these lego games were like.  I have only played it about 2 hours and I really have to force myself to play it so I am guessing these kinds of games are not for me.Basically it is a scripted story with a collecting mechanic.  The basic game play is:Watch a cinematic, then act out some event from the story, such as sneaking out of the shire while the dark riders are looking for you.   In between these events are semi-open areas (which I think you can eventually get fast travel to and take the story your own pace).  This is where the collecting comes in.  There are NPCs with missions who want certain objects.  So you run around trying to find and collect these objects.I find this kind of game play very dull and so, my interest in the game is fairly weak.  You could watch some lets play of the beginning of the game (it would take several hours to get enough game-play to make a good judgement) on if you would like it.One problem I suppose is that I already know the LOTR story so well that the whole story aspect doesn't offer me any incentive to play the game.  That is probably the big reason this game does not appeal to me.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												This might be the best Lego game yet.  It's definitely Lord of the Rings, with the strong story, setting and atmosphere - and yet its all Lego, with the silliness and sandbox gameplay you come to expect.The map is brilliant - much better than hanging around in the Cantina or the Batcave, you can roam around all of Middle Earth while you're not doing missions.  The addition of quests is very nice, as is the additional puzzles outside of the combat playgrounds.Instead of episodic gameplay, this game manages to keep the transitions from being jarring between gameplay modes, which helps keep the illusion in place that its one seamless epic.Great game!

Posted: November 23, 2016
												In a word: Fantastic.In a long, boring review: This game follows the path of the LOTR movies. The dialogue of the characters is also taken directly from the movie, as well as the actions and movements (although, Lego does put their own spin on some scenes). The exact mimicry of the movie scenes in the Lego LOTR game feels needlessly repetitive and somewhat dull, but Lego throws enough humor into the mix to keep things interesting.Perhaps the best feature of the game is the open-world aspect that is Middle Earth. When you're not following the main path in the game, you can go just about anywhere in Middle earth. You can take up quests in places like the village of Bree and Gondor. You can go to lands like Rohan and Moria. It's not greatly huge like the actual Middle Earth in the movies; in fact, it's kind of small (I could see Minas Tirith from Edoras, for crying out loud!). Nonetheless, it can take a person a while to get around the map, especially if they do all the levels. Also, there are plenty of quests to undergo that will have you go all over the map. In short, this game is a pleasant diversion and worth money and effort.So, please. BUY IT NOW!!!!!!

												As a huge LOTR fan, I enjoyed my time with LEGO The Lord of the Rings. It's an interactive guided tour through three incredible films that relives all of the most memorable moments. Posted: March 29, 2016
												If you've played any of the lego games you'll have a fair idea of what this one is all about. It follows the LoTR story relatively well (obviously it takes liberties) and the story mode took me about 10 hours on the first play-through.Essentially, you smash your way across the landscape, picking up lego 'studs' (money) solving puzzles and fighting lego monsters. The story is very linear, and it's not at all difficult. A couple of the puzzles were a bit touch and go... for example, I couldn't figure out how to kill Shelob the giant spider for quite a while... but it generally feeds everything to you on a plate, leaving you with what is essentially a hand-held but enjoyable little play through the LoTR universe... albeit in lego form.You can play all the way from start to finish unlocking areas as you go, without having to go back and repeat anything... but if you want to, you can unlock characters and go back to do parts of the game that you had trouble with earlier.If you're even remotely OCD then this one will really wind you up. There are so many little bits and pieces to complete (optional if you're not a completionist) but getting 100% of everything on every level is going to be quite a long haul.I've unlocked around 25% of the game after 12 hours... and that's just the easy stuff.The strength of this one is in the ability to go back after you've done the story mode and find all the extra little bits and pieces that you missed the first time. For example - there's a secret level where you get to play Sauron and smash up a miniature Middle Earth. I won't say where.There are dozens of characters to unlock. You can buy them with the 'studs' as you find them, and go back and collect the lot later on.There is no character progression to speak of, but there is a very simple crafting system, which allows you to exchange mithril bricks for items that you can discover and unlock on your travels.I wasn't expecting to enjoy this one as much as I did. I bought it for my little girl to play with, and thought I'd give it a try first. Suddenly, I realised I was hooked.Cons... the biggest one is the save system, which seems to be rubbish. A few times I had to repeat sections I thought I'd completed, because I hadn't found a statue which acted as a save-point.  Once you're in "free-play" mode after completing the story, however, you can save whenever you want.Other than that, and a few annoying camera angles, the game is extremely good. A light-weight explorer/platformer in the lego LoTR universe. Much fun.

												This game is AWESOME. The LEGO games have reached a new level of greatness. LEGO LOTR is not only funny, sweet and full of lovely details, it is an open-world game with the levels perfectly fitted in this world. Posted: April 19, 2014
												Let me start off by saying there are parts of this I really liked. The humor implemented around the movie dialog I thought was well done, and many of the gameplay aspects of it were done well. I've been a fan of the Lego movie games since the first Lego Star Wars, and gameplay-wise this game does some really cool things that I haven't seen before in any of their previous installments. The game itself was just as fun as every other Lego game I've ever played.That being said...The bugs are too numerous. The number of times I've had to restart a level or a puzzle because a boss got himself stuck in the ground or an object flies off into space randomly or something along these lines was....well....a pretty big number. Far too big. Not to mention it also caused my computer to completely freeze up multiple times to the point where ctrl-alt-delete doesn't even work and a hard reset is required. I'm running a pretty decent rig that has no problems whatsoever with Far Cry 3 on 1080p in ultra settings, so I don't see it being my computer at fault here. I want to love this game. But reading on some sites and in forums that this company doesn't patch their games at all, I recommend it cautiously. Just know that it might frustrate you way more often than you want a Lego game to.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												I've completed the game and while I still found the controls and camera to be your worst enemy, the game has a great open world and so much to discover that it will keep you busy for a lot of hours. You have to play through all 18 story level for the game to 'open up', but then it becomes much more fun to play and the control and camera issues are that important anymore. Also when playing the level in free play mode discovering the hidden areas and finding all the secrets really adds a lot to the game.While the early game play makes you want to hit your head against a wall, the longer you play, the better the game gets. There are still very rough edges in the game, but overall I really enjoyed playing it.The old version: The game is interesting and has a lot of content to unlock, but the controls are some of the worse I ever had to endure. The fixed camera during the 'instances' and the horrible close-up one during the free roam bits totally ruins the game. Combine that with horribly imprecise controls and a hard to guess 3D perspective and you have a game that is difficult for no other reason than messed controls and camera.If you endure the awful controls you might find a game that gives you hours of content, but I would recommend not to waste too much money to find out.

												Awesome game. Instantly delivers. Real voice actors and soundtracks from the movie. If played with controller and with friends co-op it's even more awesome!I can only praise the game how cool it actually is, but there are few negatives I'd like to point out:1. There are often 3-4 characters you need to switch between. It would be really helpful to have the character names visible at all times. Also the controls for fast character switch work between two character and you need to use the Y button to choose the other two, strange.2. The coin hunting is somewhat annoying as about every bush and stone is destroyble with fists (ehh) and coins explode everywhere. And many of them even end up going to unreachable areas.3. Every character has it's own inventory so it's kinda annoying to find the right character to complete a certain puzzle or use a certain item.That's about all negatives I can think of. For me there has been no crashes or any bugs whatsoever.On a scale 0-5 I would give this game 4.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												I'm not going to review this game as a whole, but compare it with other LEGO videogames. This one manages to stay true to it's formula, while still introducing some news. The best thing is that it recreates the The Lord of the Rings trilogy brilliantly, resuming it's story, adding voice acting and music from the films, and adding a hub composed of a mini Middle-Earth, with lots to explore. All the great scenes are here, and plenty of humor. In the end, it's not a big step forwand, but a very good LEGO videogame. However, there are some issues. Changing characters and items in free play can take some time, and doing so repeatedly can be annoying. And the game has more bugs and glitches than i expected: for example sometimes you can get stuck and have to restart the level, the game can break your 100% progression, and the 3D platforming can be awful at times. But despite that, it's a very enjoyable game, especially if you're a LEGO videogame and LotR fan.

Posted: August 8, 2016
												I think there are many iterations of LOTR games out there. Some based on single movies. Some include them all. Many I've seen poorly adapt scenes from the movie into gameplay that doesn't always fit. Or they'll force levels and gameplay that doesn't really go with the movies at all. The Lego LOTR game is great in that it encompasses all three films with stunning attention to detail. Just about every major sequence from the films is included in this game in one form or another, either as a cutscene, or as a cleverly incorporated aspect of gameplay. You name it. It's probably in there. Remember when the hobbits meet Aragorn for the first time and escape to Weathertop? Remember "second breakfast"? Well, there's a sequence of gameplay where you actually make second breakfast (which subsequently causes the ring wraiths to spot you). It can be that granular. It's amazing. Ultimately, if you're looking for a game that gives the most fulfilling gaming experience of actually playing through all three films in a single package (and you don't mind Lego looks and humor), then this game is for you. There are tons of characters and "treasures" to unlock. And what's great is being able to traverse an open-world Middle Earth (albeit it's a bit minaturized in scale).My only negatives are the sometimes repetitive nature of gameplay. If you've played any other modern Lego game you'll know what I'm talking about. Also, horses. There are some moments you ride horses in between levels as a part of the story, but you can't spawn a horse on command which would be GREAT for free roam. Granted, there are quite a few quick-travel locations, but there's nothing really outside of a less-than-adequate nonessential item which helps you get around quicker.Also, the buggyness. I don't know how common it is, but there were a few points where the game graphically glitched out that caused me to have to close out completely....which was hard because the menu became invisible at this point. Also, there was a level in which you control Frodo and Sam and have to collect Orc armor to disguise yourselves to escape. Usually, you can get a character to drop a disposable object from your inventory so that the other can pick it up. Well, in this particular situation, if you grab more of the armor pieces than the character needs, you will need to restart because the game won't let you drop it for the other character to pick it up.There's also quite a few other sporadic blips and glitches that were kind of annoying but would take too long to mention them in a review, however, when the game was running smoothly, it was a blast.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												This is a fun game, especially if you like Lego's but...1. Lego games are clearly made with Co-op in mind and this is no exception, so that means you need two controllers or a keyboard and a controller + a friend if you want the full experience, though you can still play alone alright.2. It is one of the buggier games out there. The bugs are not many but when they do show up they are somewhat game-breaking. For example, the Sauron fight at the very beginning is sometimes bugged to the point that you have to restart the game and you can't skip the long intro to that fight. The Xbox controller suddenly began to cut out every minute or so, killing your character unless you disconnect and reconnect it in time.3. The game is poorly ported from the consoles. You can quickly tell that you were not supposed to play this with the keyboard and there is no guarantee that it will support a non-xbox controller. Unless you already play games with a controller, you have to ask yourself if you are going to buy one just for this game?4. This is not a big problem, but you will quickly notice that the actors sound like someone with a cheap mic just recorded Lord of The Rings when it was on TV and put those recordings in the game.Some of the pro's are:- Co-op is well integrated into the gameplay for multiple players to feel useful.- Graphics and sound are...well they are Lego graphics and sound; they are fun if you are into that sort of thing- There are a lot of secrets, little puzzles and stuff to do. Pleasant level design overall.- Girls seem to like this game so you may get your partner to co-op

Posted: September 19, 2016
												Buggy, buggy, buggy.  I spend the first half hour of the game researching how to get past bugs that were impeding my progress.It's also a great example of a badly ported game.This is my first Lego game, and I'm pretty unimpressed with the gameplay.  It consists of running to a spot and pressing the key it tells you to press.  Sometimes you have to press it rapidly.  Sometimes you have to hold it.  Sometimes you have to switch to a specific character to press the key.  But that's it.  The only other gameplay mechanic is smashing bushes to see what falls out.  Takes me back to my NES Zelda days, but it's not fun.The cutscenes and voice acting are the best parts of the game.  They've taken Lego liberties with the story to keep it moving fast.  You will appreciate this more if you're familiar with the source material.  Overall, it delivers what it promises:  A cutesy Lego romp through the LOTR.  I couldn't finish it though.  I know the plot already and the gameplay couldn't hold me.

Posted: October 13, 2016
												Lego: The Lord of the Rings is a game that exceeded my expectations. That said, I was not expecting much when I bought it when it was on sale. However, I was thoroughly entertained from start to finish by the amusing cutscenes, and enjoyed the easy-going nature of the game. As a fan of the books and movies, I have to say that this is a game worthy of them. The art direction is beautiful. I think that the world of Lego and Middle-earth was well melded. Certain drawbacks would be the inability to roam around freely to other parts when the storyline has not been completed. I found myself having to multi-task (as a single player) to get the treasure boxes. But this doesn't draw away the fact that this is a really fun game. I'm going to go back to the game and find friends to play co-op with, and roam about with, too.

Posted: April 19, 2014
												Let me start off by saying there are parts of this I really liked. The humor implemented around the movie dialog I thought was well done, and many of the gameplay aspects of it were done well. I've been a fan of the Lego movie games since the first Lego Star Wars, and gameplay-wise this game does some really cool things that I haven't seen before in any of their previous installments. The game itself was just as fun as every other Lego game I've ever played.That being said...The bugs are too numerous. The number of times I've had to restart a level or a puzzle because a boss got himself stuck in the ground or an object flies off into space randomly or something along these lines was....well....a pretty big number. Far too big. Not to mention it also caused my computer to completely freeze up multiple times to the point where ctrl-alt-delete doesn't even work and a hard reset is required. I'm running a pretty decent rig that has no problems whatsoever with Far Cry 3 on 1080p in ultra settings, so I don't see it being my computer at fault here. I want to love this game. But reading on some sites and in forums that this company doesn't patch their games at all, I recommend it cautiously. Just know that it might frustrate you way more often than you want a Lego game to.

Posted: April 4, 2016
												This game is AWESOME. The LEGO games have reached a new level of greatness. LEGO LOTR is not only funny, sweet and full of lovely details, it is an open-world game with the levels perfectly fitted in this world. There are so many things to collect, many sidequests and great backgrounds. The synchronisation has some nice speakers (even if it isn't great) and the characters have a great design. Posted: March 29, 2016
												If you've played any of the lego games you'll have a fair idea of what this one is all about. It follows the LoTR story relatively well (obviously it takes liberties) and the story mode took me about 10 hours on the first play-through.Essentially, you smash your way across the landscape, picking up lego 'studs' (money) solving puzzles and fighting lego monsters. The story is very linear, and it's not at all difficult. A couple of the puzzles were a bit touch and go... for example, I couldn't figure out how to kill Shelob the giant spider for quite a while... but it generally feeds everything to you on a plate, leaving you with what is essentially a hand-held but enjoyable little play through the LoTR universe... albeit in lego form.You can play all the way from start to finish unlocking areas as you go, without having to go back and repeat anything... but if you want to, you can unlock characters and go back to do parts of the game that you had trouble with earlier.If you're even remotely OCD then this one will really wind you up. There are so many little bits and pieces to complete (optional if you're not a completionist) but getting 100% of everything on every level is going to be quite a long haul.I've unlocked around 25% of the game after 12 hours... and that's just the easy stuff.The strength of this one is in the ability to go back after you've done the story mode and find all the extra little bits and pieces that you missed the first time. For example - there's a secret level where you get to play Sauron and smash up a miniature Middle Earth. I won't say where.There are dozens of characters to unlock. You can buy them with the 'studs' as you find them, and go back and collect the lot later on.There is no character progression to speak of, but there is a very simple crafting system, which allows you to exchange mithril bricks for items that you can discover and unlock on your travels.I wasn't expecting to enjoy this one as much as I did. I bought it for my little girl to play with, and thought I'd give it a try first. Suddenly, I realised I was hooked.Cons... the biggest one is the save system, which seems to be rubbish. A few times I had to repeat sections I thought I'd completed, because I hadn't found a statue which acted as a save-point.  Once you're in "free-play" mode after completing the story, however, you can save whenever you want.Other than that, and a few annoying camera angles, the game is extremely good. A light-weight explorer/platformer in the lego LoTR universe. Much fun.

Posted: July 28, 2015
												Even for the Lego games, this one stands out a bit.  There's a lot of really nice mechanics in this game.  Standard fare of a lot of different characters with different abilities, but this one lets you get items that can also bestow abilities, including better versions of normal abilities.  Plus a compliment of fun powers to have.  Large overworld map to explore, many things to do, and the game itself is quite fun.  Very worth it, particularly when it's on sale!It does share the same engine bugs that all the Lego games do.  Sometimes things can get stuck.  But I didn't find anything truly game breaking (even though one on Mount Doom came close - I had to save and exit at the end, and when I returned the credit for the stuff I'd collected was wonky.  Running the map another time, and recollecting everything, fixed it.)  There is also a very, VERY annoying glitch on some jumping puzzles where the mechanic designed to prevent your character from falling off of platforms can actually prevent him from being able to jump ONTO platforms.  Some jumping puzzles can be hair-pullingly frustrating due to this.

I still like the sets, I still like the games. LEGO has a certain charm that keeps you coming back, and wanting to play more and more of it. But this game especially is amazing. It's not too long, and not too short either. It's worth the price, for sure. It has the right amount of LEGO goofiness in it, as with every LEGO game. I would give LEGO The Lord of the Rings an overall 8.5/10, as it's lacking in some areas, and I very much wish there were online multiplayer options.

Posted: November 19, 2016
												I wish reviews had a meh button because this one would be the biggest meh out of everythingStory:It’s LOTR (movie version) and sticks to the script pretty well. You play missions in order as defined by the movies and the appropriate characters are there as well. It’s good to remember the movie and play along with it but honestly, it just made me want to watch the movie instead of playing/ It does skip a lot of scenes like anything to do with Boromir’s dad, Rohan needing to be convinced to help Gondor, and anything to do with Arwen. It’s weird to see a lot of character progression and story telling go right out the window because it couldn’t be incorporated into gameplay which is understandable but I feel a better balance could have been met.Lego tries to throw slapstick into the mix which is appreciated to highlight comedy but LOTR is dark as ♥♥♥♥ so that contrast between people dying and comedy bits don’t really mesh “well” together. It’s the same problem LOTR HP-2 had; death and misery doesn’t lend itself to good slapstick.Gameplay:It’s a lego game. You do minor puzzles, break everything, and collect studs. Pretty simple stuff. HOWEVER, they actually added new components to the game. There are open and expansive hub worlds where you can do side quests, collect even more things, and get to the next missions. Unlike HP, it’s not one central hub that goes to each level but many hub worlds combined. You also use the silver bricks (used to be gold) to actually craft items which you might need for more collecting or sidequests. It’s nice to see them actually put effort to actually innovate. However, I never ended up doing any of the side quests because a lot of them required backtracking through the different hub worlds which wouldn’t be a problem because there is fast travel except for the fact that they are huge and mostly empty. Plus, the map is just absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥and doesn’t open with just tab for some reason. Hell, it’s hard to even tell where you are and which direction you need to go to find everything. I never wanted to explore the hub worlds either because they were empty and they usually required me to explore them after the game ended and ♥♥♥♥ that noise. Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)The game looks fine. It’s high res with all that encompases. The character models are especially good. However, the hub world rocks just look terrible as they’re just textures. All of the dialogue is taken from the movies but has just absolutely terrible audio mixing because they picked up background noise and their levels/emotions don’t match the visuals. It’s super distracting and I wish they had done it better. At Least the game ran fine at 144hz. Plus, the amount of dialogue vs grunts was good (looking at you Lego movie the videogame). Final Thoughts:Do I regret playing it? No. It was fun enough and what I expected out of a Lego game. A lot of care and effort was clearly put into the game which is much appreciated. But overall, they need a lot of work to actually be great. Everything from the basic gameplay, to the lack of story depth and consistency, and audio work needs work. I wish I could just say meh but whatever.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												In a word: Fantastic.In a long, boring review: This game follows the path of the LOTR movies. The dialogue of the characters is also taken directly from the movie, as well as the actions and movements (although, Lego does put their own spin on some scenes). The exact mimicry of the movie scenes in the Lego LOTR game feels needlessly repetitive and somewhat dull, but Lego throws enough humor into the mix to keep things interesting.Perhaps the best feature of the game is the open-world aspect that is Middle Earth. When you're not following the main path in the game, you can go just about anywhere in Middle earth. You can take up quests in places like the village of Bree and Gondor. You can go to lands like Rohan and Moria. It's not greatly huge like the actual Middle Earth in the movies; in fact, it's kind of small (I could see Minas Tirith from Edoras, for crying out loud!). Nonetheless, it can take a person a while to get around the map, especially if they do all the levels. Also, there are plenty of quests to undergo that will have you go all over the map. In short, this game is a pleasant diversion and worth money and effort.So, please. BUY IT NOW!!!!!!

Posted: October 13, 2016
												Lego: The Lord of the Rings is a game that exceeded my expectations. That said, I was not expecting much when I bought it when it was on sale. However, I was thoroughly entertained from start to finish by the amusing cutscenes, and enjoyed the easy-going nature of the game. As a fan of the books and movies, I have to say that this is a game worthy of them. The art direction is beautiful. I think that the world of Lego and Middle-earth was well melded. Certain drawbacks would be the inability to roam around freely to other parts when the storyline has not been completed. I found myself having to multi-task (as a single player) to get the treasure boxes. But this doesn't draw away the fact that this is a really fun game. I'm going to go back to the game and find friends to play co-op with, and roam about with, too.

Posted: September 19, 2016
												Buggy, buggy, buggy.  I spend the first half hour of the game researching how to get past bugs that were impeding my progress.It's also a great example of a badly ported game.This is my first Lego game, and I'm pretty unimpressed with the gameplay.  It consists of running to a spot and pressing the key it tells you to press.  Sometimes you have to press it rapidly.  Sometimes you have to hold it.  Sometimes you have to switch to a specific character to press the key.  But that's it.  The only other gameplay mechanic is smashing bushes to see what falls out.  Takes me back to my NES Zelda days, but it's not fun.The cutscenes and voice acting are the best parts of the game.  They've taken Lego liberties with the story to keep it moving fast.  You will appreciate this more if you're familiar with the source material.  Overall, it delivers what it promises:  A cutesy Lego romp through the LOTR.  I couldn't finish it though.  I know the plot already and the gameplay couldn't hold me.

The game is almost entirely voiced, not something that was expected going in (Up to that point, I had gotten used to the miming Minifigs acing out scenes like it was a silent movie) though the voice acting Isn't anything to write home about, it's all lines from the movies lip-synched to the minifigs mouth-movements, which, because the movies came out as early as 2002, don't sound so great now. Posted: July 28, 2015
												Even for the Lego games, this one stands out a bit.  There's a lot of really nice mechanics in this game.  Standard fare of a lot of different characters with different abilities, but this one lets you get items that can also bestow abilities, including better versions of normal abilities.  Plus a compliment of fun powers to have.  Large overworld map to explore, many things to do, and the game itself is quite fun.  Very worth it, particularly when it's on sale!It does share the same engine bugs that all the Lego games do.  Sometimes things can get stuck.  But I didn't find anything truly game breaking (even though one on Mount Doom came close - I had to save and exit at the end, and when I returned the credit for the stuff I'd collected was wonky.  Running the map another time, and recollecting everything, fixed it.)  There is also a very, VERY annoying glitch on some jumping puzzles where the mechanic designed to prevent your character from falling off of platforms can actually prevent him from being able to jump ONTO platforms.  Some jumping puzzles can be hair-pullingly frustrating due to this.

												Lego LoTR is a bug-ridden mess. I loved the other games (on the 360), like Batman, Star Wars, Indiana Jones, and Harry Potter, but this one is a constant source of frustration.Crashes. Posted: April 22
												Good game. The story is following all 6 books and 3 movies quite good, but with some humourous cinema cadres faithful to the LEGO games tone. The game is quite demanding, sometimes camera working is little lame, so i wouldnt rate it as "for child". It's more for the teens, and adults which are fan of movie and want to have a great time. Game has a lot of collectables, to gain them all you must use powers of both good and bad characters, the logical quests are interesting, so aside the story mode it has a lot of replayablity potetnial.

Posted: April 23
												Turns out walking into Mordor was very simple after all. What the hell was Boromir talking about?!Anyway, I had so much fun with this game. The Lord of the Rings films are my absolute favourites so being able to play through the epic trilogy was just awesome, especially since Middle-earth has been made into a freely explorable open world which makes it even better. And because it's a LEGO game you of course get some great humour and a ton of laughs throughout your journey.I'll definitely be returning to Middle-earth again. This is the best LEGO game in my opinion. Or should I say... "One LEGO game to rule them all." :)

INTRODUCTIONAfter going through my regular searches for steam sales I stubbled accross this particular game that was $5, and knowing my history with privious LEGO® games such as; LEGO®: Star Wars and LEGO®: Indiana Jones, I thought I might as well get it to kinder to my child self. I played a GOOD 45 hours of this game, so i feel the need to write a review on it.Pros+ Many unlockable characters + Fun gameplay+ Funny cutscenes+ Great for all ages+ Good for casaul play+ Controller compatible+ NostalgicCons- Voice acting cuts outs, and maybe hard to follow for people who don't watch the LOTR movies- Using a mouse is not an option and you will have to use only the keyboard to play- Minor bugs/crashesCONCLUSIONAside from a few bugs here and there, the game is definitely worth the money.FINAL RATING8/10
